caption_original:
A new daycare facility is a step closer to being built in Iqaluit, Nunavut. Today, the Government of Canada announced it has signed a contract with EVOQ Architecture to design the daycare that can accommodate about 60 children and employ up to 12 people.  http://ow.ly/IbbJ30e9aff

Left to Right: Tundra Buddies Day Care Society President Rachel Théorêt-Gosselin, INAC Nunavut Regional Office Regional Director General David Rochette and EVOQ Architecture Director Alain Fournier at the site where the new daycare will be built.
caption_cleaned: A new daycare facility is a step closer to being built in Iqaluit, Nunavut. Today, the Government of Canada announced it has signed a contract with EVOQ Architecture to design the daycare that can accommodate about children and employ up to people. Left to Right: Tundra Buddies Day Care Society President Rachel Théorêt-Gosselin, INAC Nunavut Regional Office Regional Director General David Rochette and EVOQ Architecture Director Alain Fournier at the site where the new daycare will be built.

caption_original:
World Oceans Day is celebrated later in the summer in the Arctic because of ice conditions. 
The 31st Iqalukpik Jamboree, Oceans Day and the Anguniaqvia niqiqyuam Marine Protected Area celebrations are coming up on August 11, 2017 in Paulatuk, Northwest Territories. http://ow.ly/4L7k30ejQ4T
caption_cleaned: World Oceans Day is celebrated later in the summer in the Arctic because of ice conditions. The st Iqalukpik Jamboree, Oceans Day and the Anguniaqvia niqiqyuam Marine Protected Area celebrations are coming up on August , in Paulatuk, Northwest Territories.

caption_original:
For World Oceans Day in the Arctic, community members of Paulatuk, Northwest Territories, came together to honour their important relationship with the Arctic Ocean.

Paulatuk is a community on the forefront of ocean protection and conservation, investing time and efforts to help designate the Anguniaqvia niqiqyuam Marine Protected Area, Canada’s first Marine Protected Area with conservation objectives based on Indigenous traditional knowledge. http://ow.ly/UoL430esD5w
caption_cleaned: For World Oceans Day in the Arctic, community members of Paulatuk, Northwest Territories, came together to honour their important relationship with the Arctic Ocean. Paulatuk is a community on the forefront of ocean protection and conservation, investing time and efforts to help designate the Anguniaqvia niqiqyuam Marine Protected Area, Canada’s first Marine Protected Area with conservation objectives based on Indigenous traditional knowledge.

#IndigenousLanguages

caption_original: New, multi-year funding agreements with 33 boards and committees in the Northwest Territories established under the Inuvialuit, Gwich’in, Sahtu and Tlicho treaties will provide the support they need to carry out their roles in the stewardship of natural resources. http://ow.ly/Gc2r30eFP08

caption_original: You can cross the Arctic circle here during your expedition in the "land that never melts." Akshayuk Pass, a traditional Inuit corridor, is a popular and challenging hiking destination where you walk through peaks, ice and wild streams. http://ow.ly/ikY330eOXKr #IndigenousLanguages

caption_original: At nearly a half-million square kilometres, the Yukon makes up 4.8 % of the total land mass of Canada, and covers a territory larger than these 4 European countries combined: the Netherlands, Germany, Belgium and Denmark!  To find out more about this vast territory that 38,300 people call home, visit: http://ow.ly/DJXe30e5nRP

caption_original: Quttinirpaaq, meaning 'Top of the World' in Inuktitut, is the name of the world's most northern national park (the North Pole is only 800 km away). This region in Nunavut provides adventurers with mountain views, below-zero summer temperatures and a chance to experience the midnight sun. http://ow.ly/DH4S30esqdO #IndigenousLanguages

This region in Nunavut provides adventurers with mountain views, below-zero summer temperatures and a chance to eerience the midnight sun.

caption_original: Happy Discovery Day to all Yukoners!  A good opportunity to highlight the territory's evolving history, including the conclusion of land claim and self-government agreements by 11 Yukon First Nations, including the Tr’ondëk Hwëch’in, who saw thousands of newcomers arrive in their territory during the Klondike Gold Rush.  Check out Mapping the Way for more information about Yukon First Nation land claims and self-government.
caption_cleaned: Happy Discovery Day to all Yukoners! A good opportunity to highlight the territory's evolving history, including the conclusion of land claim and self-government agreements by Yukon First Nations, including the Tr’ondëk Hwëch’in, who saw thousands of newcomers arrive in their territory during the Klondike Gold Rush. Check out Mapping the Way for more information about Yukon First Nation land claims and self-government.

caption_original: The Avataq Cultural Institute is the Inuit cultural organization of Nunavik (Northern Quebec). A real cultural leader for Inuit in Nunavik, the Institute acts as an important resource in Canada and beyond. Take a look at their online gallery where you can explore up to 1,400 artifacts, sculptures and works on paper by Inuit artists in Nunavik: http://ow.ly/knxw30eDe3I #Inuit GovCan - Indigenous Peoples

caption_original: The Kwanlin Dün Cultural Centre is located in Whitehorse, Yukon, and serves as the capital city's largest meeting place for both Indigenous and non-Indigenous people. In addition to being used for various gatherings such as conventions and weddings, the facility showcases the art and culture of the Kwanlin Dün First Nations. http://ow.ly/12NA30ewig4
